edge: The Daniels, co-directors of 'Everything Everywhere All at Once', began researching the concept of the multiverse as early as 2010, after being exposed to the concept of modal realism in the Ross McElwee documentary 'Sherman's March'.

In early drafts of the screenplay, the directors planned for the main character to be a professor with undiagnosed ADHD. This idea was developed after one of the co-directors, Daniel Kwan, learned that he had undiagnosed ADHD through his research for this project.

Initially, the lead character in the new script was named Michelle Wang, after the film's lead actress Michelle Yeoh. However, the character's name was eventually changed to Evelyn due to Yeoh's opposition as she believed that 'Evelyn deserves her own story to be told' and did not want to integrate herself into the character.

Kwan talked about whitewashing with studios, "The casting was probably one of the hardest things of the whole process. They're like, 'Oh, should we try a white actor?'...or 'Should we find other types of people that might actually bring in the money?'"
The Daniels had a negative experience with a dedicated post-production studio for their previous film Swiss Army Man, leading them to do visual effects post-production in-house for this film.
